item.title: Abrogation of verses in Quran
item.description: Introduction Abrogation (naskh) in the Qur’an refers to the concept that some verses were revealed with specific rulings that were later replaced or superseded by other verses. The idea is that earlier verses, while initially applicable, were later abrogated by new revelations that provided clearer or more comprehensive rulings. Shah Waliullah Dehlavi, a prominent Islamic scholar and reformer from India, contributed extensively to Islamic thought and jurisprudence. He is known for his works on tafsir, fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence), and hadith, and he also made significant contributions to the understanding of abrogation (naskh) in the Qur’an.
